summary.para: An Interface for accessing assets and performing operations on assets.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.FindAssets(System.String)

summary.para: Search the assetdatabase using a searchfilter string.

You can search for names, lables and types (classnames). 'name': filter assets by their filename (without extension). Words separated by whitespace becomes seperate name searches. Use quotes if two or more words should be considered one word. 'labels': Use the keyword 'l'. Filtering by more than one label will return assets if just one asset label is matched (OR'ed) 'types': Use the keyword 't'. Filtering by more than one type will return assets if just one type is matched (OR'ed). Types can be either builtin types e.g 'Texture2D' or user script class names. If all assets are wanted: use 'Object' as all assets derive from Object.

member.param: The filter string can contain search data for: names, asset labels and types (class names). See description for more info.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.FindAssets(System.String,System.String[])

summary.para: Search the assetdatabase using a searchfilter string.

You can search for names, lables and types (classnames). 'name': filter assets by their filename (without extension). Words separated by whitespace becomes seperate name searches. Use quotes if two or more words should be considered one word. 'labels': Use the keyword 'l'. Filtering by more than one label will return assets if just one asset label is matched (OR'ed) 'types': Use the keyword 't'. Filtering by more than one type will return assets if just one type is matched (OR'ed). Types can be either builtin types e.g 'Texture2D' or user script class names. If all assets are wanted: use 'Object' as all assets derive from Object.

member.param: The filter string can contain search data for: names, asset labels and types (class names). See description for more info.
Specifying one or more folders will limit the searching to these folders and their child folders (and is faster than searching all assets).

summary.para: Is object an asset?
Returns true when an object is an asset (corresponds to a file in the Assets folder), and false if it is not (for example object in the scene, or an object created at runtime).
Is object an asset?
Returns true when an object is an asset (corresponds to a file in the Assets folder), and false if it is not (for example object in the scene, or an object created at runtime).

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.CreateFolder(System.String,System.String)

summary.para: Create a new folder.

member.param: The name of the parent folder.
The name of the new folder.

returns.para: The GUID of the newly created folder.

summary.para: Is asset a main asset in the project window?
For example an imported model has a game object as its root and several Meshes and child game objects in expanded state. The root game object is the main asset in this case.
Is asset a main asset in the project window?
For example an imported model has a game object as its root and several Meshes and child game objects in expanded state. The root game object is the main asset in this case.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.IsSubAsset(UnityEngine.Object)

summary.para: Does the asset form part of another asset?
Some assets may form part of another asset (for example, a procedural material can be part of a material package). This function tells if an asset is subordinated in this way.

member.param: The asset Object to query.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.IsSubAsset(System.Int32)

summary.para: Does the asset form part of another asset?
Some assets may form part of another asset (for example, a procedural material can be part of a material package). This function tells if an asset is subordinated in this way.

member.param: Instance ID of the asset Object to query.

summary.para: Creates a new unique path for an asset.
All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png".
Begin Asset importing. This lets you group several asset imports together into one larger import.
Stop Asset importing. This lets you group several asset imports together into one larger import.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.ValidateMoveAsset(System.String,System.String)

summary.para: Checks if an asset file can be moved from one folder to another. (Without actually moving the file).
All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png".

member.param: The path where the asset currently resides.
The path which the asset should be moved to.

returns.para: An empty string if the asset can be moved, otherwise an error message.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.MoveAsset(System.String,System.String)

summary.para: Move an asset file from one folder to another.
All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png".

member.param: The path where the asset currently resides.
The path which the asset should be moved to.

returns.para: An empty string if the asset has been successfully moved, otherwise an error message.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.RenameAsset(System.String,System.String)

summary.para: Rename an asset file.
All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png".

member.param: The path where the asset currently resides.
The new name which should be given to the asset.

returns.para: An empty string, if the asset has been successfully renamed, otherwise an error message.

summary.para: Moves the asset at path to the trash.

Returns true if the asset has been successfully removed, false if it doesn't exit or couldn't be moved to the trash. All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png" See Also: AssetDatabase.DeleteAsset.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.DeleteAsset(System.String)

summary.para: Deletes the asset file at path.
Returns true if the asset has been successfully deleted, false if it doesn't exit or couldn't be removed.

member.param: Filesystem path of the asset to be deleted.

summary.para: Import asset at path.
All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png"
Import asset at path.
All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png"

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.CopyAsset(System.String,System.String)

summary.para: Duplicates the asset at path and stores it at newPath.

Filesystem path of the new asset to create.

summary.para: Writes the import settings to disk.
In order to make the cache server import assets.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.CreateAsset(UnityEngine.Object,System.String)

summary.para: Creates a new asset at path.
You must ensure that the path uses a supported extension ('.mat' for materials, '.cubemap' for cubemaps, '.GUISkin' for skins, '.anim' for animations and '.asset' for arbitrary other assets.)

member.param: Object to use in creating the asset.
Filesystem path for the new asset.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.AddObjectToAsset(UnityEngine.Object,System.String)

summary.para: Adds objectToAdd to an existing asset at path.
Please note that you should only add assets to '.asset' assets, imported models or texture assets for example will lose their data.

member.param: Object to add to the existing asset.
Filesystem path to the asset.

summary.para: Adds objectToAdd to an existing asset identified by assetObject.
Please note that you should only add assets to '.asset' files, imported models or texture assets for example will lose their data when reimporting or quitting Unity.
Returns the path name relative to the project folder where the asset is stored.
All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png".
Returns the path name relative to the project folder where the asset is stored.
All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png".
Returns the path name relative to the project folder where the asset is stored.
All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png" When a game object is part of a scene, the scene path is returned.

summary.para: Gets the path to the text .meta file associated with an asset.

member.param: The path to the asset.

returns.para: The path to the .meta text file or empty string if the file does not exist.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.LoadAssetAtPath(System.String,System.Type)

summary.para: Returns the first asset object of type type at given path assetPath.

Some asset files may contain multiple objects. (such as a Maya file which may contain multiple Meshes and GameObjects). All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png".

member.param: Filesystem path of the asset to load.
Data type of the asset.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.LoadMainAssetAtPath(System.String)

summary.para: Returns the main asset object at assetPath.
All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png"

member.param: Filesystem path of the asset to load.

summary.para: Returns all asset representations at assetPath.
Asset representations are objects in the asset that are visible in the Project view. All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png"

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AssetDatabase.LoadAllAssetsAtPath(System.String)

summary.para: Returns an array of all asset objects at assetPath.

Some asset files may contain multiple objects (such as a Maya file which may contain multiple Meshes and GameObjects). All paths are relative to the project folder, for example: "Assets/MyTextures/hello.png"

member.param: Filesystem path to the asset.

summary.para: Import any changed assets.
This will import any assets that have changed their content modification data or have been added-removed to the project folder.
Import any changed assets.
This will import any assets that have changed their content modification data or have been added-removed to the project folder.
Opens the asset with associated application.

Opens asset in an external editor, texture application or modelling tool depending on what type of asset it is. If it is a text file, lineNumber instructs the text editor to go to that line. Returns true if asset opened successfully.
Opens the asset with associated application.

Opens asset in an external editor, texture application or modelling tool depending on what type of asset it is. If it is a text file, lineNumber instructs the text editor to go to that line. Returns true if asset opened successfully.
Opens the asset(s) with associated application(s).
Opens asset in an external editor, texture application or modelling tool depending on what type of asset it is. Returns true if all assets opened successfully.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.EditorGUI.HandlePrefixLabel(UnityEngine.Rect,UnityEngine.Rect,UnityEngine.GUIContent,System.Int32)

summary.para: Make a label for some control.

HandlePrefixLabel is like PrefixLabel but allows custom control over the label position by supplying its Rect explicitly. PrefixLabel or HandlePrefixLabel should be used when creating a control with a connected label. It ensures that when the label is clicked, the control will get keyboard focus. For this reason it is important that the same ID is supplied to PrefixLabel or HandlePrefixLabel as to the control itself. It is also possible to not supply a Control ID, in which case the one from the immediately following control is automatically used.

member.param: Rectangle on the screen to use in total for both the label and the control.
Rectangle on the screen to use for the label.
Label to show for the control.
The unique ID of the control. If none specified, the ID of the following control is used.

PrefixLabel or HandlePrefixLabel should be used when creating a control with a connected label. It ensures that when the label is clicked, the control will get keyboard focus. For this reason it is important that the same ID is supplied to PrefixLabel or HandlePrefixLabel as to the control itself. It is also possible to not supply a Control ID, in which case the one from the immediately following control is automatically used.

member.param: Rectangle on the screen to use in total for both the label and the control.
Rectangle on the screen to use for the label.
Label to show for the control.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.EditorGUI.GetPropertyHeight(UnityEditor.SerializedProperty,UnityEngine.GUIContent)

summary.para: Get the height needed for a PropertyField control.

The height is based on the type of the SerializedProperty, and inclues the height of all expanded children if the includeChildren parameter is set to true, which is the default. If the property has a custom PropertyDrawer, the function will return the height returned by that drawer. The includeChildren parameter is ignored in that case, as PropertyDrawers always include children.

member.param: Height of the property area.
Descriptive text or image.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.EditorGUI.GetPropertyHeight(UnityEditor.SerializedProperty)

The includeChildren parameter is ignored in that case, as PropertyDrawers always include children.

member.param: Height of the property area.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.EditorGUI.FocusTextInControl(System.String)

summary.para: Move keyboard focus to a named text field and begin editing of the content.

In Editor GUI, text fields can have keyboard focus without the text being edited. For example you may switch focus between text fields or other controls by using the up and down arrow keys. Once you click inside the text field, editing of the text itself begins and the arrow keys are then used to navigate the text content.

member.param: Name set using GUI.SetNextControlName.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.EditorGUI.BeginDisabledGroup(System.Boolean)

summary.para: Create a group of controls that can be disabled.
If disabled is true, the controls inside the group will be disabled. If false, the enabled/disabled state will not be changed.

member.param: Boolean specifying if the controls inside the group should be disabled.

summary.para: Ends a disabled group started with BeginDisabledGroup.
See Also: BeginDisabledGroup.
Check if any control was changed inside a block of code.
When needing to check if GUI.changed is set to true inside a block of code, wrap the code inside BeginChangeCheck () and EndChangeCheck () like this:
Ends a change check started with BeginChangeCheck ().
See Also: BeginChangeCheck.

returns.para: True if GUI.changed was set to true, otherwise false.

summary.para: Makes the following controls give the appearance of editing multiple different values.
This is sometimes useful when creating custom editors and you want to represent a value in a non-standard way in the GUI while also supporting multi-object editing.
Is the platform-dependent "action" modifier key held down? (Read Only)
The key is Command on Mac OS X, Control on Windows.

The label to show.
Optional GUIStyle.

returns.para: The foldout state selected by the user. If true, you should render sub-objects.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.EditorGUILayout.ToggleLeft(System.String,System.Boolean,UnityEngine.GUILayoutOption[])

summary.para: Make a toggle field where the toggle is to the left and the label immediately to the right of it.
EditorGUILayout.ToggleLeft is similar to GUILayout.Toggle but respects the EditorGUI.showMixedValue property and handles keyboard focus consistent with other Editor controls.

member.param: Label to display next to the toggle.
The value to edit.

An optional list of layout options that specify extra layouting properties. Any values passed in here will override settings defined by the style.
See Also: GUILayout.Width, GUILayout.Height, GUILayout.MinWidth, GUILayout.MaxWidth, GUILayout.MinHeight, GUILayout.MaxHeight, GUILayout.ExpandWidth, GUILayout.ExpandHeight.

summary.para: Lets you do move, copy, delete operations over files or directories.
Deletes a file or a directory given a path.
This function's path is relative to the project root folder but it can also accept absolute paths.
Copies a file or a directory.
This function's path can be relative to the project root folder or be an absolute path.
Copies the file or directory.
Copies from
Moves a file or a directory from a given path to another path.
This function's path is relative to the project root folder but it can also accept absolute paths.
Returns a unique path in the Temp folder within your current project.
The returned path is relative to the project folder.
Replaces a file.

Replaces the file located at dst with the file located at src. if dst doesnt exists it just copies the file. If dst exists then it deletes it and copies the file at src to dst See Also: FileUtil.ReplaceDirectory.
Replaces a directory.

Replaces the directory located at dst with the directory located at src. if dst doesnt exists it copies the file. If dst exists then it deletes it and copies the directory at src to dst See Also: FileUtil.ReplaceFile.
GameObject utility functions.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.GameObjectUtility.SetParentAndAlign(UnityEngine.GameObject,UnityEngine.GameObject)

summary.para: Sets the parent and gives the child the same layer and position.

This is intended as a utility function when creating custom GameObjects with a MenuItem in the "GameObject/" menu. When using the context click menu to create new GameObjects in the scene hierarchy, the newly created GameObjects should be parented to the clicked GameObject, which is passed in as MenuCommand.context. Calling this method ensures this behavior in the case of a context click while doing nothing if the context is null (see example on the MenuItem docs).

member.param: The GameObject that should have a new parent set.
The GameObject that the child should get as a parent and have position and layer copied from. If null, this function does nothing.

summary.para: Gets the set StaticEditorFlags.
Returns true if the passed in StaticEditorFlags are set.
Sets the StaticEditorFlags.
Get the navmesh layer for the GameObject.
Get the navmesh layer from the layer name.
Set the navmesh layer for the gameobject.
Get all the navmesh layer names.
Describes information and value of a single shader property.
MaterialProperty is used with
Material objects being edited by this property (Read Only).
Changes done to property values via floatValue, colorValue, vectorValue, textureValue will be applied to these objects.
Type of the property (Read Only).
Material properties can be textures, colors, floats and so on. Depending on the type, you should use textureValue, colorValue, vectorValue or floatValue to access the property value.
Name of the property (Read Only).
This is the variable name that is used in the shader, for example _MainTex.
Display name of the property (Read Only).
This is the user-visible property name, for example "Main Texture" that is declared in the shader's Properties block.
Flags that control how property is displayed (Read Only).
Texture dimension (2D, Cubemap etc.) of the property (Read Only).
See Also: type, textureValue.
Min/max limits of a ranged float property (Read Only).
This is only relevant for MaterialProperty.PropType.Range properties.
Does this property have multiple different values? (Read Only)
When multiple materials are selected at once, some of their properties can have different values.
Color value of the property.
Setting a new value will apply it to all material
Vector value of the property.
Setting a new value will apply it to all material
Float vaue of the property.
Setting a new value will apply it to all material
Texture value of the property.
Setting a new value will apply it to all material
Material property type.
Material properties can be textures, colors, floats and so on.
Color property.
See Also: MaterialProperty.type.
Vector property.
See Also: MaterialProperty.type.
Float property.
See Also: MaterialProperty.type.
Ranged float (with min/max values) property.
See Also: MaterialProperty.type.
Texture property.
See Also: MaterialProperty.type.
Texture dimension of a property.
Texture properties can accept regular (2D) textures, Cubemaps etc.
No texture type is set.
See Also: MaterialProperty.textureDimension.
Texture2D property.
See Also: MaterialProperty.textureDimension.
Texture3D property.
See Also: MaterialProperty.textureDimension.
Cubemap property.
See Also: MaterialProperty.textureDimension.
Texture property accepts any texture type.
See Also: MaterialProperty.textureDimension.
Flags that control how a MaterialProperty is displayed.
No flags are set.
Do not show the property in inspector.
MaterialEditor will not show this property. This corresponds to "[HideInInspector]" attribute in front of property in the shader code.

Texture value for this property will be queried from renderer's MaterialPropertyBlock, instead of from the material. This corresponds to "[PerRendererData]" attribute in front of property in the shader code.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AlphabeticalSort.Compare(UnityEngine.GameObject,UnityEngine.GameObject)

summary.para: Sort the gameobjects by name.

member.param: LHS gameobject to sort.
RHS gameobject to sort.

summary.para: Content to visualize the alphabetical sorting method.
Custom 3D GUI controls and drawing in the scene view.

Handles are the 3D controls that Unity uses to manipulate items in the scene view. There are a number of built-in Handle GUIs, such as the familiar tools to position, scale and rotate an object via the Transform component. However, it is also possible to define your own Handle GUIs to use with custom component editors. Such GUIs can be a very useful way to edit procedurally-generated scene content, "invisible" items and groups of related objects, such as waypoints and location markers.
Clears the camera.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Handles.PositionHandle(UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Quaternion)

summary.para: Make a 3D Scene view position handle.

This will behave like the built-in move tool in Unity. If you have assigned something to Undo.SetSnapshotTarget, it will work fully with Undo. If you have assigned a non-null value to ignoreRaycastObjects, the center handle will support full raycast placement. To control the orientation of the handle, set Handles.matrix prior to calling this function.

member.param: Center of the handle in 3D space.

returns.para: Use HandleUtility.GetHandleSize where you might want to have constant screen-sized handles.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Highlighter.Highlight(System.String,System.String)

summary.para: Highlights an element in the editor.

This function will highlight the specified element in the specified window. If the element could not be found, the function returns false. If the element is inside a scrollview and is not currently visible, the scrollview will first automatically scroll to reveal the element and then highlight it.

member.param: The title of the window the element is inside.
The text to identify the element with.

returns.para: false if the requested element was found; otherwise false.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.Highlighter.Highlight(System.String,System.String,UnityEditor.HighlightSearchMode)

summary.para: Highlights an element in the editor.

This function will highlight the specified element in the specified window. If the element could not be found, the function returns false. If the element is inside a scrollview and is not currently visible, the scrollview will first automatically scroll to reveal the element and then highlight it.

member.param: The title of the window the element is inside.
The text to identify the element with.
Optional mode to specify how to search for the element.

returns.para: false if the requested element was found; otherwise false.

The identifier text of the rect.

The rect in screenspace of the current active highlight.

Describes the various version control states an asset can have.
The version control state is unknown.
The asset is not under version control.
The asset is up to date.
A newer version of the asset is available on the version control server.
The asset exists in version control but is missing on the local machine.
This can happen if you delete an assets from Finder/Explorer with out using the version control system.
The asset has been checked out on the local machine.
The asset has been checked out on a remote machine.
The asset has been deleted locally.
The asset has been deleted on a remote machine.
The was locally added to version control.
Remotely this asset was added to version control.
If the same assets exists on two machine but has only been added to version control on one of them, then it will appear as remotely added on the machine where it has not been added.
There is a conflict with the asset that needs to be resolved.
The asset is locked by the local machine.
The asset is locked by a remote machine.
The state of the asset is currently being queried from the version control server.
The asset is read only.
This instance of the class actaully refers to a .meta file.
A list of version control information about assets.

summary.para: Start a task that will resolve conflicting assets in version control.

When conflicting assets appear you can resolve it by using your own copy or the incoming copy. A third way of resolving the conflict is by first Provider.Merge() the assets and the resolve using the merged asset. Use the resolveMethod to flag what should be used.

summary.para: Return version control information about the currently selected assets.
Gets the currently user selected verson control plugin.

Returns true if the version control provider is enabled and a valid Team License was found.
Returns true if a version control plugin has been selected and configured correctly.
This is true if a network connection is required by the currently selected version control plugin to perform any action.

E.g. before doing anything using Perforce you need to checkout the asset, in order to do that a connection to the server is required where as subversion does not require access to the server to do changes to an asset.
Returns the OnlineState of the version control provider.
Returns the reason for the version control provider being offline (if it is offline).

An AnimationClipCurveData object contains all the information needed to identify a specific curve in an AnimationClip. The curve animates a specific property of a component / material attached to a game object / animated bone.
See Also: AnimationUtility, ObjectNames.
The path of the game object / bone being animated.
The type of the component / material being animated.
The name of the property being animated.
The actual animation curve.
Defines how a curve is attached to an object that it controls.
The transform path of the object that is animated.
The property of the object that is animated.
Editor utility functions for modifying animation clips.
Sets the array of AnimationClips to be referenced in the Animation component.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.AnimationUtility.SetEditorCurve(UnityEngine.AnimationClip,UnityEditor.EditorCurveBinding,UnityEngine.AnimationCurve)

summary.para: Adds an editor curve to the given clip.

Unity automatic combines position curves, scale curves, rotation curves internally. Thus transform curves always get combined and their keyframes is always the union of all keyframe points. In the Editor AnimationClip's let you specify special editor curves which do not get combined, thus it lets the user edit curves in a more intuitive way.

member.param: The animation clip to which the curve will be added.
The bindings which defines the path and the property of the curve.
The curve to add.

summary.para: Retrieves all curves from a specific animation clip.
If includeCurveData is false, all animation curves in returned results will be null. Use this when you only want to get the list of curves, their types and names.
Retrieves all curves from a specific animation clip.
If includeCurveData is false, all animation curves in returned results will be null. Use this when you only want to get the list of curves, their types and names.
Retrieves all animation events associated with the animation clip.
Replaces all animation events in the animation clip.
Calculates path from root transform to target transform.

Returns a string representing the path in a transform hierarchy from a given root transform down to a given target transform. The root transform does not need to be an actual root, but it must be higher in the hierarchy than the target transform. The target and root may also be the same transform.
AnimationMode is used by the AnimationWindow to store properties modifed by the AnimationClip playback.

When exiting AnimationMode all properties are reverted to their default state. Animated properties are also highlighted by the inspector. Use AnimationMode.StartAnimationMode to enter animation mode. In Animation mode the editor is tinted to show that it is animating. Properties can be animated via AnimationMode.SampleAnimationClip.
Is the specified property currently in animation mode and being animated?
Stops Animation mode, reverts all properties that were animated in animation mode.
AnimationMode stores per property modifications. They are added either via AnimationMode.SampleClip or AnimationMode.AddPropertyModification. StopAnimationMode reverts all of these properties.
Are we currently in AnimationMode.
Starts the animation mode.
When the Animation Mode is enabled, the editor is tinted in a special color to indicated that animations are playing and recorded.
Samples an AnimationClip on the object and also records any modified properties in AnimationMode.

This function must always be surrounded by AnimationMode.BeginSample and AnimationMode.EndSample. When a property is no longer sampled (through SampleAnimationClip or AddPropertyModification) between BeginSample and EndSample it will automatically revert to the original value when EndSample is called.
The color used to show that a property is currently being animated.
The asset should be moved to trash.
Delete the asset without moving it to the trash.
Asset importing options.
See Also: AssetDatabase.ImportAsset, AssetDatabase.Refresh.
Default import options.
See Also: AssetDatabase.ImportAsset, AssetDatabase.Refresh.
User initiated asset import.
This should be passed when asset import is caused by the user (e.g. by clicking Reimport). Non-user initiated import happens when the asset modification time changes.
Import all assets synchronously.

By default some assets can be imported asynchronously (e.g. scripts can be compiled in the background). In some cases all importing needs to be synchronous; use this flag then. For example, when importing a scripts + prefabs, scripts have to be fully compiled before prefab is serialized, otherwise it might get old variables.
When a folder is imported, import all its contents as well.
See Also: AssetDatabase.ImportAsset, AssetDatabase.Refresh.
Force a full reimport but don't download the assets from the cache server.
See Also: AssetDatabase.ImportAsset, AssetDatabase.Refresh.
Forces asset import as uncompressed for edition facilities.
See Also: AssetDatabase.ImportAsset, AssetDatabase.Refresh.
Building options. Multiple options can be combined together.
See Also: BuildPipeline.BuildPlayer.
Perform the specified build without any special settings or extra tasks.
Build a development version of the player.
A development build includes debug symbols and enablesthe
Run the built player.
See Also: BuildPipeline.BuildPlayer.
Show the built player.
See Also: BuildPipeline.BuildPlayer.
Build a compressed asset bundle that contains streamed scenes loadable with the WWW class.

This allows you to on demand load scenes and their assets when needed instead of a simple linear progressing download. The best way to build a streamed scene asset bundle is to use BuildPipeline.BuildStreamedSceneAssetBundle See Also: BuildPipeline.BuildPlayer.
Used when building XCode (iPhone) or Eclipse (Android) projects.
On iPhone, this setting will append an existing XCode project. Existing XCode project setting changes will be preserved.
Copy UnityObject.js alongside Web Player so it wouldn't have to be downloaded from internet.
See Also: BuildPipeline.BuildPlayer.
Start the player with a connection to the profiler in the editor.
See Also: BuildPipeline.BuildPlayer.
Allow script debuggers to attach to the player remotely.
Note that script debugging is not supported on the webplayer.

See Also: BuildPipeline.BuildPlayer.
Don't compress the data when creating the asset bundle.
This makes it faster to build & load, but since it is much bigger it will take longer to download.
Generate online version of webplayer.

Generate HTML for the webplayer which references the Unity-hosted version of UnityObject2.js. When this option is not used the HTML will reference a copy of UnityObject2.js which will be dropped into the build folder alongside the HTML. This version of UnityObject2.js is easier to work with, and allows you to debug Javascript locally.
Asset Bundle building options.
See Also: BuildPipeline.BuildAssetBundle.
Includes all dependencies.
This follows all references to any assets, game objects or components and includes them in the build.
Forces inclusion of the entire asset.
For example if you pass a Mesh into the BuildPipeline.BuildAssetBundle function and use CompleteAssets it would also include the game object and any animation clips in the same asset.
Do not include type information within the AssetBundle.

Specifying this flag will make an AssetBundle susceptible to script or Unity version changes, but will make the file smaller and a bit faster to load. This flag affects only AssetBundles for platforms that have type information included by default. Mobile and console platform always build without type information. Type information must be present for Web platforms, therefore Unity will reject to build an AssetBundle if you specify this flag when building for BuildTarget.WebPlayer, for example.
Builds an asset bundle using a hash for the id of the object stored in the asset bundle.

This allows you to rebuild an asset bundle and reference assets in it directly. When rebuilding the asset bundle the objects in it are guaranteed to have the same id after rebuilding the asset bundle. Due to it being a 32 bit hash space, if you have a lot of objects in the asset bundle it will increase the potential for hash conflicts. Unity will give an error and not build the asset bundle in that case. The hash is based on the GUID of the asset and the local id of the object in the asset. DeterministicAssetBundle are also slower to load from than normal asset bundles, this is because the threaded background loading API usually expects objects to be ordered in a way that makes reading reduce seeking. With DeterministicAssetBundles that is not possible.
Don't compress the data when creating the asset bundle.
This makes it faster to build & load, but since it is much bigger it will take longer to download.
Lets you programmatically build players or AssetBundles which can be loaded from the web.
Lets you manage cross-references and dependencies between different asset bundles and player builds.

If no path is specified, the path of the current open scene is used, except if it was never saved before, in which case a save dialog is shown.

summary.para: Get the height used for a single Editor control such as a one-line EditorGUI.TextField or EditorGUI.Popup.

When creating your own multi-line controls, such as controls for custom classes with multiple fields, you can use EditorGUILayout.GetControlRect and pass in a height value that is a multiple of EditorGUIUtility.singleLineHeight. This is advisable over hardcoding specific pixel values. See Also: EditorGUILayout.GetControlRect.
Get the height used by default for vertical spacing between controls.

When creating GUI without GUILayout, such as is for instance required by PropertyDrawers, and you need to place several controls under each other, you can use standardVerticalSpacing to ensure there's the proper standard spacing between the controls. This is advisable over hardcoding specific pixel values. See Also: EditorGUILayout.GetControlRect.
Is the user currently using the pro skin? (Read Only)
Get a white texture.
Is a text field currently editing text?

In Editor GUI, text fields can have focus without the text being edited. For example you may switch focus between text fields or other controls by using the up and down arrow keys. Once you click inside the text field, editing of the text itself begins and the arrow keys are then used to navigate the text content. editingTextField is true when a text field is in this text editing mode.
Is the Editor GUI is hierarchy mode?

In hierarchy mode, EditorGUI.Foldout controls are positioned with the foldout triangle to the left of the specified Rect for the control, rather than being inside the Rect. This way, the label of the foldout is aligned together with labels of other Editor GUI controls.
Is the Editor GUI currently in wide mode?

Wide mode is a mode for Editor GUI where the controls for structs such as Vector3 and Rect are inlined so they take up less vertical space. For example, in wide mode a Vector3Field takes up one line height instead of two, and a RectField takes up two line heights instead of three.
The width of the GUI area for the current EditorWindow or other view.
The width in pixels reserved for labels of Editor GUI controls.

Editor GUI controls have a certain width allocated for labels. This width can be changed by setting labelWidth to a different value. Setting it to 0 will reset the label width to the default value. The default value can vary, for example depending on the width of the Inspector window.
The minimum width in pixels reserved for the fields of Editor GUI controls.

Most Editor GUI controls consist of a label as well as the control field itself. The minimum width of the field is controlled by the fieldWidth value. Fields often appear wider than the minimum width, since Editor GUI controls are usually set to occupy a

member.name: M:UnityEditor.HandleUtility.CalcLineTranslation(UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector2,UnityEngine.Vector3,UnityEngine.Vector3)

summary.para: Map a mouse drag onto a movement along a line in 3D space.

Certain types of Handles (such as arrows) involve movement along a line in 3D space. For example, the Transform's position arrows move the object along its local X, Y or Z axis as the mouse is dragged. The CalcLineTranslation function converts the movement of the mouse into constrained movement along a 3D line in the familiar way used by Unity's built-in tools.

member.param: The source point of the drag.
The destination point of the drag.
The 3D position the dragged object had at src ray.
3D direction of constrained movement.

returns.para: The distance travelled along constraintDir.

summary.para: Returns the parameter for the projection of the point on the given line.
The return value can be negative if the projected point is in negative lineDirection relative to the linePoint/ See Also: ProjectPointLine.
Project point onto a line.
See Also: DistancePointLine. See Also: PointOnLineParameter.
Calculate distance between a point and a line.
See Also: ProjectPointLine.
Calculate distance between a point and a Bezier curve.
See Also: Handles.DrawBezier function.
Pixel distance from mouse pointer to line.
Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the line between
Pixel distance from mouse pointer to camera facing circle.
Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the circle at given world space
Pixel distance from mouse pointer to a rectangle on screen.
Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the rectangle.
Distance from a point p in 2d to a line defined by two points a and b.
Distance from a point p in 2d to a line segment defined by two points a and b.
Pixel distance from mouse pointer to a 3D disc.
Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the disc (circle) at given world space
Get the point on an disc (in 3D space) which is closest to the current mouse position.

This function takes the disc defined by its parameters and "flattens" it into screen space. The closest point between the flattened disc and the current mouse position (also in screen space) is then found and converted back into a 3D point on the original 3D disc. This is useful for Handle GUIs that involve rotation of an object around the center of the disc; the 2D mouse movements are converted into 3D space in the familiar way used by Unity's built-in tools.
Pixel distance from mouse pointer to a 3D section of a disc.
Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the disc section at given world space
Get the point on an arc (in 3D space) which is closest to the current mouse position.

This function takes the arc defined by its parameters and "flattens" it into screen space. The closest point between the flattened arc and the current mouse position (also in screen space) is then found and converted back into a 3D point on the original 3D arc. This is useful for Handle GUIs that involve rotation of an object around the center of the arc; the 2D mouse movements are converted into 3D space in the familiar way used by Unity's built-in tools.
Pixel distance from mouse pointer to a polyline.
Calculates the screen space distance from the mouse pointer to the multi segment line that goes through the given world space points.
Get the point on a polyline (in 3D space) which is closest to the current mouse position.

A polyline is simply a zigzag line defined by a set of points connected in sequence. The ClosestPointToPolyLine function takes the polyline defined by a point array and "flattens" it into screen space. The closest point between the flattened line and the current mouse position (also in screen space) is then found and converted back into a 3D point on the original 3D polyline. This is useful for Handle GUIs that involve manipulating an arbitrary 3D shape using the mouse; the 2D mouse movements are converted into 3D space in the familiar way used by Unity's built-in tools. An example of where this might be used is a racetrack defined by a set of waypoints - a position along the track line could be selected via the mouse using ClosestPointToPolyLine.

summary.para: Pick game object closest to specified position.
Store all camera settings.

The camera settings will be added to a so-called "stack" list, where they will stay until retrieved by a call to PopCamera. The settings will be stored in the reverse of the order in which they were added, so a call to PopCamera will retrieve the most recently stored Camera data and then remove it from the stack. A subsequent call to PopCamera will then retrieve the next most recently pushed data and so on.
Retrieve all camera settings.
A call to PopCamera will retrieve the most recently stored Camera settings added to a "stack" structure by PushCamera. This allows for easy saving and restoration of temporary camera changes.

Lets you register undo operations on specific objects you are about to perform changes on.

summary.para: Records any changes done on the object after the RecordObject function.

Almost all property changes can be recorded with this function. The transform parent, AddComponent, object destruction can not be recorded with this function, for that you should use the dedicated functions.
Records multiple undoable objects in a single call. This is the same as calling Undo.RecordObject multiple times.

Perform an Redo operation.
This performs a redo operation. It is the same as clicking on the Edit->Redo menu. See Also: PerformUndo.
Unity automatically groups undo operations by the current group index.

The current group is automatically incremented based on events eg. mouse down events, executing a menu item increments the current group. But sometimes it is necessary to manually group undo operations.
Unity automatically groups undo operations by the current group index.
The current group index is automatically increased on mouse down, clicking on menu items and other operations.
Performs the last undo operation but does not record a redo operation.
This is useful when you want to simply revert the last performed action. In Unity the escape is commonly used to execute this function.
Performs all undo operations up to the group index without storing a redo operation in the process.

Collapses all undo operation up to group index together into one step.

The internal implementation will not try to move the asset on disk, but will move it in the internal database to keep consistency.
Tells the internal implementation that the callback did not delete the asset. The asset will be delete by the internal implementation.
Tells Unity that the file cannot be deleted and Unity should leave it alone.
Tells Unity that the asset was deleted by the callback. Unity will not try to delete the asset, but will delete the cached version and preview file.

Material search options for ModelImporter.
See Also: ModelImporter.materialSearch.
Searh in local Materials forlder.

Unity will try to locate the material in local Materials folder, i.e. in path modelFilePath/Materials. For example: if model is Assets/Model/MyModel.fbx, then it will try to locate the material in Assets/Model/Materials folder. See Also: ModelImporter.materialSearch.
Recursive-up search in Materials forlders.

Unity will perform a recursive-up search for the material in all Materials folders up to the Assets folder. For example: if model is Assets/Model/MyModel.fbx, then it will try to locate the material in these folders in this order: Assets/Model/Materials, Assets/Materials. See Also: ModelImporter.materialSearch.
Searh in all project.
Unity will search for the material in all folders of Unity project. See Also: ModelImporter.materialSearch.
Animation generation options for ModelImporter.
See Also: ModelImporter.normalImportMode, ModelImporter.tangentImportMode.
Import normals/tangents from file.
See Also: ModelImporter.normalImportMode, ModelImporter.tangentImportMode.
Calculate normals/tangents.
It is recommended to use Import mode as long as you can - use Calculate only if you don't have normals/tangents in your file.
Strip normals/tangents.
If normals/tangents are not needed by all shaders, this can be a simple way to reduce build size a little.
Mesh compression options for ModelImporter.
Compressing meshes saves space in the built game, but more compression introduces more artifacts in vertex data.
No mesh compression (default).
See Also: ModelImporter.meshCompression.
Low amount of mesh compression.
Vertex positions, normals/tangents and UVs will be quantized to respectively 20, 8, 16 bits per component. Skinning information will be compressed.
Medium amount of mesh compression.
Vertex positions, normals/tangents and UVs will be quantized to respectively 16, 8, 10 bits per component. Skinning information will be compressed.
High amount of mesh compression.
Vertex positions, normals/tangents and UVs will be quantized to respectively 10, 6, 8 bits per component. Skinning information will be compressed.
Animation compression options for ModelImporter.
Compressing animations saves space in the built game, but more compression introduces more artifacts in the animations.
No animation compression.
See Also: ModelImporter.animationCompression.
Perform keyframe reduction (default).
See Also: ModelImporter.animationCompression.
Perform keyframe reduction and compression.
See Also: ModelImporter.animationCompression.

Settings of this class match the ones exposed in Mesh Import Settings.
Import materials from file.

When set to false ModelImporter will use default material (Default-Diffuse.mat) instead of imported materials, otherwise it will find existing or create new materials based on materialName and materialSearch options. See Also: materialName, materialSearch options.
Material naming setting.

When importing new model Unity will generate material name based on this setting and then it will try to locate existing material with such name, if no such material exists Unity will create a new material by that name. See Also: ModelImporterMaterialName, materialSearch, importMaterials.
Existing material search setting.
When importing new model Unity will try to find existing materials in a set of folders based on this setting. See Also: ModelImporterMaterialSearch, materialName, importMaterials.
Global scale factor for importing.
Is useFileUnits supported for this asset.
UseFileUnits is supported only on .max files.
Detect file units and import as 1FileUnit=1UnityUnit, otherwise it will import as 1cm=1UnityUnit.

This setting is used only for .max files. It was introduced for backwards compatibility: there is a bug in some FBX 2011 plugins - they fail to pick up file units and export everything as 1unit=1cm. We fixed that problem by setting the units manually, but that breaks projects which were built with FBX 2011 plugins already, so useFileUnits was introduced as a solution. Set it to false if you want to default to centimeters in FBX exporter.
Controls import of BlendShapes.
Add mesh colliders to imported meshes.
Smoothing angle for calculating normals.
How sharp the edge has to be to be turned into a hard edge when calculating normals. This setting is only used when normalImportMode is set to Calculate.
Should tangents be split across UV seams.
This setting is only used when tangentImportMode is set to Calculate.
Swap primary and secondary UV channels when importing.
Generate secondary UV set for lightmapping.

Threshold for area distortion when generating secondary UV.
Hard angle for generating secondary UV.
Margin to be left between charts when packing secondary UV.
Animation generation options.

Generates the list of all imported Transforms.
Generates the list of all imported Animations.
Are mesh vertices and indices accessible from script?

Making a mesh readable will keep two copies of it in memory, one for rendering and one in system memory for script access. Setting isReadable to false therefore saves memory. Scaling a mesh with different amounts along the three axes (i.e. non-uniform scaling) requires the mesh to be readable for correct lighting.
Vertex optimization setting.

The vertices and indices will be reordered for better GPU performance. Techniques that require strict vertex ordering like mesh morphing or special particle mesh emitter effects should have this option disabled.

In the GameObjects hierarchy of a character, the GameObjects which only contain Transform component, will be optimized out unless they are specified in extraExposedTransformPaths for better CPU performance. The remaining GameObjects hierarchy will be flattened.
Animation optimization setting.

Animation compression setting.
Compressing animations saves space in the built game, but more compression introduces more artifacts in the animation data.
Allowed error of animation rotation compression.
Allowed error is defined in angle (in degrees) between compressed and original quaternions on a curve. This settings used only when animation keyframe reduction is enabled.
Allowed error of animation position compression.
Allowed error is defined in distance (in percents) between compressed and original positions on a curve. This settings used only when animation keyframe reduction is enabled.
Allowed error of animation scale compression.
Allowed error is defined in distance (in percents) between compressed and original scale on a curve. This settings used only when animation keyframe reduction is enabled.

Font rendering mode constants for TrueTypeFontImporter.
Use Anti-Aliased Font rendering. When using dynamic fonts, this is the mode which is fastest in rendering font textures.
This mode looks very similar to the font rendering on Mac OS X.
Use Anti-Aliased Font rendering with hinting. This forces character lines to run along pixel boundaries, and generally produces.

A crisper output then FontRenderingMode.Smooth, more similar to the font rendering used on Windows. It is slower to render textures then when using smooth mode, but may be easier to read for small font sizes.
Use hinted font rendering without anti-aliasing. This is the crispest font rendering option, and may be most readable for small.
Font sizes.
Use the OS default font rendering mode. This selects either FontRenderingMode.HintedSmooth or.

FontRenderingMode.HintedRaster on Windows, and either FontRenderingMode.Smooth or FontRenderingMode.HintedRaster on Mac OS X, depending on the system preferences. This mode is only available for dynamic fonts, as static fonts are generated at build time.
AssetImporter for importing Fonts.
Create an editable copy of the font asset at path.

Use this function if you want to modify the font generated by the TrueTypeFontImporter, with a custom texture or otherwise. It will create a copy of the font asset at path with an accompanying png Texture file and a Material, which you can all modify to meet your needs. A reference to the newly created editable Font is returned.

If this is enabled, the actual font will be embedded into the asset for Dynamic fonts.
When you disable this, the user must have the font installed in his system to use it.

summary.para: Change the mesh compression setting for a mesh.
This allows you to enable mesh compression for meshes created from scripting, which have not been generated by the ModelImporter. That way you can generate compressed mesh assets from code.

member.param: The mesh to set the compression mode for.
The compression mode to set.

member.name: M:UnityEditor.MeshUtility.GetMeshCompression(UnityEngine.Mesh)

summary.para: Returns the mesh compression setting for a Mesh.

member.param: The mesh to get information on.

summary.para: Optimizes the mesh for GPU access.

This operation might take a while but will make the geometry displayed be faster. You should use it if you generate a mesh from scratch procedurally and you want to trade better runtime performance against higher load time. Internally it converts the mesh to triangle list and optimizes the triangles and vertices for both pre and post transform cache locality. For imported models you should never call this as the import pipeline already does it for you.

Allows to control the lightmapping job.
Before starting the job the bake settings can be set via
Starts an asynchronous bake job.
The progress can be monitored via isRunning property.
Stars a synchronous bake job.
Returns when the lightmapping has finished.
Starts an asynchronous bake job for the selected objects.
The progress can be monitored via isRunning property.
Stars a synchronous bake job for the selected objects.
Returns when the lightmapping has finished.
Starts an asynchronous bake job, but only bakes light probes.
The progress can be monitored via isRunning property.
Starts a synchronous bake job, but only bakes light probes.
Returns when the lightmapping has finished.
Cancels the currently running asynchronous bake job.
Deletes all lightmap assets and makes all lights behave as if they weren't baked yet.
Only those assets are deleted that are in the folder with the same name as the scene name AND their name follows the pattern LightmapFar-#.exr or LightmapNear-#.exr.
Returns true when the bake job is running, false otherwise (Read Only).
Bake quality setting for LightmapEditorSettings.
See Also: LightmapEditorSettings.quality.
High quality bake for final renderings.
See Also: LightmapEditorSettings.quality.
Low quality bake for preview renderings.
See Also: LightmapEditorSettings.quality.
Various settings for the bake.
The bake can be started via
Boosts indirect light (Beast's diffuseBoost property, pow(colorComponent, (1.0 / diffuseBoost))).
It can be used to increase the amount of bounced light within a scene and it's cheaper than setting the number of bounces to high values.
Indirect light intensity multiplier.
The maximum width of an individual lightmap texture.
The maximum height of an individual lightmap texture.
Lightmap resolution in texels per world unit.
Last used lightmap resolution (i.e. resolution of the lightmaps currently in the scene) in texels per world unit.
Sky light color.
Sky light intensity.
Sky light can give very good results in outdoor scenes but also significantly increases bake time. Value of 0 disables sky light.
Quality of the bake.
Controls Beast's final gather and anti-aliasing settings (some of which are also exposed in Unity).
Whether to use DXT1 compression on the generated lightmaps.

Compression is recommended to improve lightmap rendering performance and lower the memory footprint, but might introduce visible artifacts in scenes without high-detail texturing that would mask-out the issues.
Number of light bounces in the global illumination computation (with 0 meaning direct light only).
Number of rays used in the final gather integrator.

Since lower number of rays leads to creating points of higher variance (so a higher contrast difference), you will probably need a higher setting for finalGatherContrastThreshold to prevent points from clumping together.
Contrast threshold between neighbouring surface points.

Above that value new final gather sample points will be created - it tells the algorithm to place points where they are really needed, so in areas where the light changes quickly. In other words, it adaptively controls the number of points.
Controls how the irradiance gradient is used in the interpolation.
Each point stores its irradiance gradient which can be used to improve the interpolation. However in some situations using the gradient can result in white halos and other artifacts.
The number of final gather points to interpolate between.
Higher values give smoother results, but can also smooth out details in the lighting.
Controls how much Ambient Occlusion to blend into the Final Gather solution.
Can be used to get more contrast in your lighting. Set to a value greater than 0 for AO to be calculated.
Beyond this distance a ray is considered to be unoccluded.
Can be used to avoid full occlusion in closed scenes.
Controls the look of the transition from black to white.
If enabled, Beast atlasing won't be run and lightmap indices, tiling and offset won't be modified on Mesh Renderers.
Texel separation between shapes.
StaticOcclusionCulling lets you perform static occlusion culling operations.
Used to compute static occlusion culling data asynchronously.
The memory limit (specified in bytes) is a hint to the PVS baking system about the likely memory requirements.
Used to cancel asynchronous generation of static occlusion culling data.
See Also: StaticOcclusionCulling.GenerateInBackground, isRunning.
Clears the PVS of the opened scene.
Used to check if asynchronous generation of static occlusion culling data is still running.
See Also: StaticOcclusionCulling.GenerateInBackground, StaticOcclusionCulling.Cancel.
Does the scene contain any occlusion portals that were added manually rather than automatically?
Returns the size in bytes that the PVS data is currently taking up in this scene on disk.
Used to visualize static occlusion culling at development time in scene view.
If set to true, visualization of target volumes is enabled.
If set to true, the visualization lines of the PVS volumes will show all cells rather than cells after culling.
If set to true, visualization of view volumes is enabled.
If set to true, visualization of portals is enabled.
If set to true, visualization of portals is enabled.
If set to true, culling of geometry is enabled.

Mac fullscreen mode.
This defines how fullscreen mode is handled in Mac OS X standalone builds.
Capture the display.

In this mode Unity will capture the display and change the hardware resolution to the requested mode. No other UI content can appear, and it is not possible to switch to other applications while in fullscreen mode.
Fullscreen window.

In this mode, Unity will create a window which is covering the whole screen. It will always run at desktop resolution, and other requested resolutions will be scaled up. OS UI will correctly show on top of the fullscreen window (such as IME input windows, GameCenter or Mac App Store UI, Battery warnings, etc). On OS X 10.7 and newer, it is possible to switch to other Applications using trackpad swipes or Cmd-Tab.
Fullscreen window with Dock and Menu bar.

Same as Fullscreen window mode, but Unity will also show the Menu bar and Dock if the cursor moves to the edges of the screen, like other OS X fullscreen Apps. It is possible to switch between fullscreen and windowed modes using the fullscreen button in the window title bar (or in the menu bar in fullscreen mode).
Direct3D 9 fullscreen mode.
This defines how fullscreen mode is handled in Windows standalone builds when using Direct3D 9.
Exclusive mode.

In this mode Unity will change the monitor resolution and claim exclusive use of the target display. Note that monitor selection is not available from the startup dialog when using exclusive mode. Also, run in background is not supported when the player is minimized.
Fullscreen window.

In this mode, Unity will create a window which is covering the whole screen. It will always run at desktop resolution, and other requested resolutions will be scaled up. OS UI will correctly show on top of the fullscreen window (such as IME input windows).

Unused parts of managed code are stripped away.
Managed method bodies are stripped away. AOT platforms only.
Lightweight mscorlib version will be used at expense of limited compatibility.
Script call optimization level.
Default setting.
Script method call overhead decreased at the expense of limited compatibility.

Target GLES graphics.
Use OpenGL ES 2.0.
Always choose OpenGL ES 2.0, even if newer API versions are available.
Use OpenGL ES 3.0.

Always try to use OpenGL ES 3.0. On Android, the APK will be marked with "Requires GL ES 3.0" in the application manifest (but only if targeting Android version 4.3 or greater). Note that the application will still attempt to fall back to OpenGL ES 2.0 if 3.0 is not available for some reason.
Automatically select the graphics API level.

Select the best graphics API based on the device capabilities. In most cases this means first attempting to create OpenGL ES 3.0 context and on failure automatically fall back to OpenGL 2.0. The developer should make sure the application works in both OpenGL ES 2.0 and 3.0 modes.

Player Settings is where you define various parameters for the final game that you will build in Unity. Some of these values are used in the Resolution Dialog that launches when you open a standalone game.
Get user-specified symbols for script compilation for the given build target group.
Set user-specified symbols for script compilation for the given build target group.
Returns whether or not the specified aspect ratio is enabled.
Aspect Ratios selectable in the Resolution Dialog will be monitor-supported resolutions of enabled items from this list.
Enables the specified aspect ratio.
Aspect Ratios selectable in the Resolution Dialog will be monitor-supported resolutions of enabled items from this list.
Returns the list of assigned icons for the specified platform.

Most platforms support viewing icons in multiple sizes so Unity lets you specify multiple icon textures for each platform. Each texture in the returned array correspond to the corresponding entry in the list of icon sizes returned by GetIconSizesForTargetGroup.
Assign a list of icons for the specified platform.

Most platforms support viewing icons in multiple sizes so Unity lets you specify multiple icon textures for each platform. The list will only be assigned if it has the same length as the list of icon sizes returned by GetIconSizesForTargetGroup and if the specified platform is supported in this editor.
Returns a list of icon sizes for the specified platform.

Most platforms support viewing icons in multiple sizes so Unity lets you specify multiple icon textures for each platform. Use this function to get the sizes to use for the specified platform, where each size specifies both the width and height in pixels.
The name of your company.
This is used to locate the preferences file.
The name of your product.
This will appear on the menu bar when your game is running and is used to locate the preferences file.
Set the color space for the current project.
This is a slow process and may cause a reimport of some assets.
Default horizontal dimension of stand-alone player window.
Default vertical dimension of stand-alone player window.
Default horizontal dimension of web player window.
Default vertical dimension of web player window.
Defines the behaviour of the Resolution Dialog on product launch.
If enabled, the game will default to fullscreen mode.
The
If enabled, your game will continue to run after lost focus.
Defines if fullscreen games should darken secondary displays.
Write a log file with debugging information.

This is useful to find out what happened if there are problems with your game. When publishing games for Apple's Mac App Store, it is recommended to turn this off, because Apple may reject your submission otherwise.
Use resizable window in standalone player builds.
By default standalone Windows, Mac and Linux builds use a non-resizable game window. Enabling this makes the window resizable.
Remove Physics code from player to save build size (Flash only).
Enable receipt validation for the Mac App Store.

This enables receipt validation for the Mac App Store. If this is enabled, your game will only run when it contains a valid receipt from the Mac App Store. Use this when submitting games to Apple for publishing on the App Store. This prevents people from running the game on any computer then the one it was purchased on.
Define how to handle fullscreen mode in Mac OS X standalones.
Set this to change how fullscreen mode is handled in Mac OS X standalone builds. See MacFullscreenMode for descriptions of the possible modes.
Define how to handle fullscreen mode in Windows standalones (Direct3D 9 mode).
Set this to change how fullscreen mode is handled in Windows standalone builds with Direct3D 9. See D3D9FullscreenMode for descriptions of the possible modes.
Force exclusive mode in DirectX 11.
Only recommended to fix Oculus vsync. There are known issues with alt-tab.
On Windows, show the application in the background if Fullscreen Windowed mode is used.

This setting is used with the Fullscreen Windowed mode. If this setting is false and you Alt-Tab out of the application, it will minimize. If this setting is true, the application will not minimize and remain visible behind other windows.
Restrict standalone players to a single concurrent running instance.
This detects at startup whether another instance of the same player is already running, and aborts with an error message if so.
First level to have access to all Resources.Load assets in Streamed Web Players.
Use this variable to specify the index of the first level that will have access to all Resources.Load assets.

This is the password for retrieving and updating the keys inside a particular keystore (known as [-storepass <storepass>] on the keytool/jarsigner command line).

SerializedObject and SerializedProperty are classes for editing properties on objects in a completely generic way that automatically handles undo and styling UI for prefabs.
SerializedObject is used in conjunction with
Create SerializedObject for inspected object.
See Also: Update.
Create SerializedObject for inspected object.
See Also: Update.
Update serialized object's representation.
Update hasMultipleDifferentValues cache on the next /Update()/ call.

Normally, you should not need to call this, as the SerializedProperty setters take care of this. However, when you change an object bypassing the SerializedProperty class, you will need to manually call this to force the difference cache to be updated.
Update serialized object's representation, only if the object has been modified since the last call to Update or if it is a script.
In which case it is not safe to assume that SetDirty has been called.
Get the first serialized property.
You can use this to go over all properties of the target object.
Find serialized property by name.
You can use this to find a specific property in the target object.
Apply property modifications.
Copies a value from a SerializedProperty to the same serialized property on this serialized object.
The inspected object (Read Only).
When multi-object editing, the targetObject property will just return the first of the edited objects. To get all the objects, use the targetObjects property instead.
The inspected objects (Read Only).
The serialized object can represent multiple objects simultaneously when multi-object editing.
Does the serialized object represents multiple objects due to multi-object editing? (Read Only)
SerializedProperty and SerializedObject are classes for editing properties on objects in a completely generic way that automatically handles undo and styling UI for prefabs.

Returns a copy of the SerializedProperty iterator in its current state. This is useful if you want to keep a reference to the current property but continue with the iteration.
Note that if you keep a reference to an array property and that array is subsequently resized then the stored reference is no longer reliable and should not be used.
Duplicates the serialized property.
The serialized property can't be used anymore after calling this function. A new iterator must be created in that case.

The serialized property can't be used anymore after calling this function. A new iterator must be created in that case.

Retrieves the SerializedProperty that defines the end range of this property.

Collect all objects in the hierarchy rooted at each of the given objects. This is most useful for linearizing entire GameObject hierarchies including all their components.

Similarly to UnloadUnusedAssets it will unload unused assets, but additionally it will also unload assets that are referenced only by the script properties or static variables. The unloaded assets will be loaded again on the first use.

AssetModificationProcessor lets you hook into saving of serialized assets and scenes which are edited inside Unity.
This lets you prevent writing of assets by Unity for integration with VCS solutions like Perforce which require locking of files.
AssetModificationProcessor lets you hook into saving of serialized assets and scenes which are edited inside Unity.
This lets you prevent writing of assets by Unity for integration with VCS solutions like Perforce which require locking of files.
AssetPostprocessor lets you hook into the import pipeline and run scripts prior or after importing assets.

In a production pipeline AssetPostprocessors should always be placed in pre-built dll's in the project instead of in scripts. AssetPostprocessors change the output of imported assets, thus a compile error in one of the scripts will lead to assets being imported differently. This can be a severe issue when working in a production pipeline. By using dll's for AssetPostprocessors you ensure that they can always be executed even if the scripts have compile errors. This way you can override default values in the import settings or modify the imported data like textures or meshes.
